messages.text: Also changed str to repr here.

messages.author: tony
messages.text: Can you make this a class too?

messages.author: tony
messages.text: Oh, you may also want to try using repr instead of str.  repr will escape things for you (into python syntax, but that's probably ok?).

messages.author: ojan
messages.text:
On 2009/08/03 18:50:30, tony wrote:
> Can you make this a class too?

I tried going down this path, but I don't think this will work. I need to write out the JSON and then later read it back in and modify it. If I make this a class, then I would access properties via .results instead of ["results"], right? But then when I read the JSON back in, it will just be a dict.

Is there a way to make that all work?

In either case, I made this a bit cleaner by putting the creation of the JSON objects behind Create* methods.

messages.author: ojan

> Oh, you may also want to try using repr instead of str.  repr will escape things
> for you (into python syntax, but that's probably ok?).

messages.author: tony
messages.text:
On 2009/08/05 17:00:18, ojan wrote:
> On 2009/08/03 18:50:30, tony wrote:
> > Can you make this a class too?
> 
> I tried going down this path, but I don't think this will work. I need to write
> out the JSON and then later read it back in and modify it. If I make this a
> class, then I would access properties via .results instead of ["results"],
> right? But then when I read the JSON back in, it will just be a dict.
> 
> Is there a way to make that all work?
> 
> In either case, I made this a bit cleaner by putting the creation of the JSON
> objects behind Create* methods.

Yeah, I thought you might need it to be a dict for the JSON conversion.  Leaving it as a dict is fine.
